questions.question_text:
An administrator is planning the deployment of a vSphere with Tanzu using an NSX-T environment and must ensure that the control plane VMs and container images are placed onto different datastores. The administrator decides to create two datastores and apply differently named tags to each datastore.

Which additional action would the administrator need to perform to meet this requirement?

choices.D: Create a single storage policy containing all tag criteria and apply to the Supervisor Cluster using the vSphere Client.
choices.C: Create two storage policies with all tag criteria and apply to the Supervisor Cluster using kubectl commands.
choices.A: Create two storage policies with different tag criteria and apply to the Supervisor Cluster using the vSphere Client.
choices.B: Create two storage policies with different tag criteria and apply to the Supervisor Cluster using kubectl commands.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Still amazed when they have the right answer.

Selected Answer: A
It's "A", these are then converted to storage classes.

A - Yes
B - No, kubectl can't see VSphere storage policies directly
C - Why would you make both policies have all tags, this is silly
D - What is being accomplished if we use the same tags when we want different workload placement, silly

questions.question_text: How do vSphere Namespaces allow different teams to share a Kubernetes cluster?

choices.D: Advertises extended resources for a node
choices.A: Attaches authorization and policy to a subsection of the cluster

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It's "A", here's why

A. Attaches authorization and policy to a subsection of the cluster - Yes, namespaces do this
B. Installs Calico CNI - No, namespaces don't do this
C. Installs a network policy provider - What does this have to do with authorisation/RBAC
D. Advertises extended resources for a node - Huh... this has nothing to do with RBAC/authentication

A Mamespaces help different projects, teams, or customers to share a Kubernetes cluster. It does this by providing the following: A scope for Names. B A mechanism to attach authorization and policy to a subsection of the cluster.

Selected Answer: A
I will go with "A", here's why: 

A. Deployment - Yes, in a deployment we define number of replicas
B. Namespaces - Close but no, the namespace definition doesn't go that low
C. Persistent Volume - This is a disk, what does this have to do with scaling pods?
D. Network Policies - This is a set of network config rules, what does this have to do with scaling pods?

"A" is the best answer.

questions.question_text: What can be used to define whether a vSphere pod can be scaled?

choices.D: From vSphere Client, navigate to the namespace, and select the option to purge unreferenced images.
choices.A: Enable the garbage collector service to purge all unreferenced images from the corresponding namespace.
choices.C: Download the vSphere Docker Credential Helper CLI Tool, and use it to purge all unreferenced images from the corresponding namespace.
choices.B: From the Harbor UI, navigate to the project associated with namespace, and select the option to purge unreferenced images.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Read the question. Purge specifically refers to selection D.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

D In the vSphere Client, navigate to the namespace.
Select Configure and select General.
Next to Embedded Registry, click Purge.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-0848998D-A530-4566-8029-534D0F2B52E0.html

questions.question_text: How can the vSphere administrator purge unused images from the image registry?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I will go with "D", here's why: 

A. vSphere Distributed Switch - this is a prerequisite but is not responsible directly for external access
B. Virtual router - This is an NSX thing and you can do Tanzu without NSX, so no
C. Internal load balancer - No, keyword internal, this is for applications to access other applications as part of a deployment
D. External load balancer - Yes, this is all about external access to resources

D is the best answer
